items.title: Google Cloud, Palo Alto ink nearly $10B AI security deal

featured_image.name: Google Cloud anticipates at least $58 billion revenue boost ...

items.description:
Alphabet's Google Cloud division and Palo Alto Networks announced Friday an expanded partnership valued at nearly $10 billion, marking the cloud provider's largest security services agreement as enterprises rush to protect AI infrastructure from escalating cyber threats[1][2][3].

The multiyear contract includes Palo Alto's commitment to migrate key internal workloads to Google Cloud and develop new AI-powered security offerings, according to a source with direct knowledge of the matter who spoke to Reuters[1][2][4]. While executives from both companies declined to comment on specific financial figures, the agreement significantly expands a strategic relationship that dates to 2018[1][2][4].

items.title: Interstellar comet makes closest approach to Earth

featured_image.name: An interstellar comet is passing by Earth tonight—here’s how to see it

items.description:
Interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS passed closest to Earth early Friday morning, zooming within 168 million miles of our planet at 1 a.m. EST before continuing its journey out of the solar system forever[1][2]. The rare celestial visitor, which originated from beyond our sun's influence, offered astronomers their best opportunity to study an object from another star system.

The comet, discovered July 1, 2025 by the ATLAS telescope survey in Chile, is only the third known interstellar object to pass through our solar system, following 1I/'Oumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019[3][4][1]. Despite traveling at more than 140,000 mph, 3I/ATLAS posed no threat to Earth, passing at nearly twice the distance between Earth and the sun[3][1].

items.title: Putin says Russia made Ukraine compromises, awaits response

featured_image.name: Putin can fund Ukraine war for years to come, ex-official says as Trump's resolve is tested

items.description:
Russian President Vladimir Putin stated Friday that Russia made compromises on Ukraine during his August summit with U.S. President Donald Trump in Alaska and is now waiting for a response from the West and Kyiv, while the Kremlin leader showed no signs of softening his territorial demands[1][2].

Speaking at his annual end-of-year press conference on December 19, Putin claimed that Moscow had been asked to make certain concessions during the Alaska meeting and agreed to them[1][2]. "The ball is in the West's and Ukraine's court," Putin said, suggesting it is now up to Ukraine and Western nations to respond to Russia's proposed compromises[1][3][4]. He praised Trump's approach to the conflict, stating the U.S. president is making "frank efforts to end the conflict" in Ukraine[1][5][6].

items.title: US stocks rise as inflation data eases Fed concerns

featured_image.name: S&P 500 futures are little changed after index ends four-day losing run: Live updates

items.description:
US stock futures climbed Friday morning, extending a powerful rally driven by unexpectedly soft inflation data and renewed optimism in artificial intelligence stocks following blockbuster earnings from memory-chip maker Micron Technology[1][2][3].

Futures for the S&P 500 rose 0.3%, while contracts for the Nasdaq 100 gained 0.5% as of Friday morning, aiming to build on Thursday's sharp gains[2][3]. The Dow Jones Industrial Average futures held near unchanged levels[2].

items.title: Maersk ship navigates Red Sea for first time in two years

featured_image.name: Maersk completes first Red Sea voyage in nearly two years

items.description:
Danish shipping giant Maersk announced Friday that one of its vessels successfully navigated the Red Sea and Bab el-Mandeb Strait for the first time in nearly two years, marking a cautious step toward resuming a critical global trade route that has been largely abandoned since Houthi militants began attacking ships in early 2024.

The Singapore-flagged container ship Maersk Sebarok completed the transit on Thursday and Friday, the company said in a statement[1][2][3]. However, Maersk emphasized it has no immediate plans to fully reopen the route, with no additional sailings currently scheduled.

"Whilst this is a significant step forward, it does not mean that we are at a point where we are considering a wider East-West network change back to the trans-Suez corridor," the company said[1][4][3]. Maersk indicated it may continue a "stepwise approach" toward resuming passage through the waterway.

items.title: EU delays Mercosur trade pact amid protests, approves $90B for Ukraine

featured_image.name: BELGIUM-AGRICULTURE-POLITICS-DEMO

items.description:
The European Union delayed signing a historic free-trade agreement with South American nations until January, bowing to violent farmer protests and opposition from France and Italy during a critical summit where leaders also secured €90 billion in financing for Ukraine's war effort.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced Friday morning that the EU-Mercosur deal, originally scheduled to be signed in Brazil this weekend, would be postponed to address remaining concerns from member states[1][2][3]. The delay came hours after more than 10,000 farmers descended on Brussels with tractors, blocking roads and clashing violently with police outside EU headquarters where leaders were meeting[1][4].

items.title: Putin holds marathon news conference as peace talks stall

featured_image.name: Live updates: Vladimir Putin holds annual live event as Trump pushes for Ukraine peace deal

items.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin held his annual end-of-year news conference on Friday, addressing around 700 journalists and millions of questions from the public in a televised event that combined his traditional press briefing with a call-in show[1][2][3]. The marathon session came as diplomatic efforts by President Donald Trump to broker a Ukraine peace deal have reached an impasse, with Putin showing little willingness to compromise on his territorial demands.

items.title: Nike profits tumble as China sales fall for sixth straight quarter

featured_image.name: Nike posts surprise sales growth, but warns of sluggish holiday season and bigger than expected tariff hit

items.description:
Nike reported a sharp 32 percent decline in quarterly profits on Thursday as sales in China fell for the sixth consecutive quarter, sending shares plunging nearly 11 percent in after-hours trading and underscoring the challenges facing the sportswear giant's turnaround efforts[1][2][3][4][5].

The company posted net income of $792 million, or 53 cents per share, for its fiscal second quarter ended November 30, down from $1.16 billion a year earlier[3][6][7]. Revenue rose 1 percent to $12.4 billion, slightly exceeding analyst expectations of $12.2 billion[8][2][3].

"Nike is in the middle innings of our comeback," CEO Elliott Hill said in a statement[3][9]. "We are making progress in the areas we prioritized first and remain confident in the actions we're taking to drive the long-term growth and profitability of our brands."

items.title: Canada, US to begin free trade talks in January

featured_image.name: Canadian PM Carney says trade talks with US resume after ...

items.description:
Canada and the United States will launch formal discussions in mid-January to review their free trade agreement, Prime Minister Mark Carney announced Thursday following a meeting with provincial leaders. Dominic LeBlanc, Canada's point person for U.S.-Canada trade relations, will meet with American counterparts to begin negotiations ahead of the agreement's mandatory review in July 2026[1][2].

The announcement comes as trade tensions persist between the two nations, with the U.S. maintaining 50% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum and 25% on automotive exports[3][4]. Trump suspended sectoral trade talks in October after the Ontario government ran anti-tariff advertisements in the United States[1][5].

items.title: Japan's MUFG invests $4.4B in India's Shriram Finance

featured_image.name: Japan's MUFG buys 20% stake in India's Shriram Finance

items.description:
Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group will acquire a 20 percent stake in Shriram Finance for $4.4 billion, the Indian non-bank lender announced Friday, marking the largest cross-border investment in India's financial sector and underscoring the growing appetite of Japanese banks for the world's most populous nation.

The Mumbai-based company's board approved issuing 471.1 million equity shares at 840.93 rupees each to MUFG Bank through a preferential allotment[1][2][3][4]. The transaction is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, including from the Reserve Bank of India and the Competition Commission of India, with an extraordinary general meeting scheduled for January 14, 2026[1].

items.title: Melting ice fuels surging sea level rise, scientists warn

featured_image.name: Earth's frozen regions are sending a clear warning about climate ...

items.description:
More than 50 leading scientists studying Earth's frozen regions have issued a stark warning: the planet's ice sheets and glaciers shed approximately 640 billion tonnes of ice in the past year alone, driving sea level rise to accelerate at an alarming pace[1][2]. The findings, published in the annual State of the Cryosphere report released in November ahead of the UN climate summit in Brazil, reveal that political resistance is undermining efforts to address the crisis[1][3][2].

The vast polar ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica lost around 370 billion tonnes of ice over the past year, while the world's 270,000 mountain glaciers shed an additional 270 billion tonnes[1][2][4]. This ice loss has contributed to sea level rise doubling from 2.1 millimeters per year in 1993 to 4.5 millimeters per year in 2024[5][6][7]. If this acceleration continues, sea levels could rise at a rate of one centimeter per year by the end of the century, forcing many coastal and island communities to relocate[1][2][4].

In February 2025, combined Arctic and Antarctic sea ice extent hit its lowest area ever recorded in the 47-year satellite record[1][3][8]. The Arctic reached its record-low maximum extent in March 2025, while Antarctica's summer minimum tied for second-lowest on record[9][10][11]. The report also confirmed that permafrost has become a net source of carbon emissions, releasing greenhouse gases roughly equivalent to the world's eighth-highest emitting country[1][12][4].

items.title: UK gets first detailed worst-case climate scenarios

featured_image.name: Experts warn ongoing concern with Atlantic Ocean will be direct ...

items.description:
British policymakers now have detailed worst-case climate scenarios for the first time, including the possibility of a 6°C temperature plunge if Atlantic Ocean currents collapse or a scorching 4°C rise by the end of the century, according to research published Thursday in the journal Earth's Future.

Scientists from the University of Reading have mapped out six long-term scenarios and multiple short-term extreme weather possibilities, filling a critical gap that left the UK unprepared for low-probability but high-impact climate outcomes. Until now, sea level rise was the only area where such extreme scenarios existed[1][2][3].

"The climate extremes we have mapped aren't predictions, but they are plausible," said Professor Nigel Arnell, lead author of the study[1][3][4]. "The UK has been planning without the tools to test against worst-case scenarios. We've now given decision-makers what they need to prepare for climate outcomes they hope never happen, but can't afford to ignore."

items.title: Senate confirms Jared Isaacman as NASA administrator

featured_image.name: What to know about Jared Isaacman, the billionaire private astronaut leading NASA

items.description:
Billionaire entrepreneur and private astronaut Jared Isaacman was sworn in Thursday as NASA's 15th administrator, concluding a year-long saga marked by political turbulence and ending the space agency's longest period without permanent leadership in recent memory[1][2].

The Senate confirmed Isaacman on Wednesday in a 67-30 vote, with all opposition coming from Democrats[3][4]. Hours after his swearing-in at the Eisenhower Executive Office Building, President Donald Trump signed an executive order setting an ambitious 2028 deadline for returning Americans to the Moon and establishing initial elements of a permanent lunar outpost by 2030[5][6][7].

"NASA's mission is as imperative and urgent as ever — to push the boundaries of human exploration, ignite the orbital economy, drive scientific discovery, and innovate for the benefit of all of humanity," Isaacman said during Thursday's ceremony[2].

items.title: Trump touts inflation drop to 2.7% as midterms approach

featured_image.name: Trump calls affordability crisis a "hoax," touts the economy ahead of midterms

items.description:
President Trump hailed unexpectedly positive inflation data released Thursday as vindication of his economic agenda, declaring "practically no inflation" hours after the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported consumer prices rose 2.7% in November—the lowest reading since July and well below Wall Street forecasts of 3.1%[1][2][3].

The timing provided a political boost for Trump, coming one day after his primetime address promising an economic boom and announcing $1,776 payments to 1.45 million service members[1][4]. With 2026 midterm elections approaching and Democrats hammering affordability concerns, the White House moved quickly to highlight the data as evidence Trump's policies are working[1][5].

items.title: Asian markets rise as US inflation cools, Japan hikes rates

featured_image.name: BOJ likely to raise rates in December, government to tolerate move, sources say

items.description:
Asian stock markets climbed on Friday as cooler-than-expected US inflation data boosted investor sentiment, while the Bank of Japan raised interest rates to a three-decade high, underscoring diverging central bank policies across major economies[1][2][3][4].

Japan's Nikkei 225 led regional gains, rising 1.3% after the BOJ lifted its key policy rate to 0.75% from 0.5%, marking its first increase since January and the highest level since 1995[2][5]. Hong Kong's Hang Seng added 0.7%, while South Korea's Kospi gained 0.8%, and the MSCI Asia-Pacific index outside Japan rose 0.7%[2][5][4].

The rally followed strong gains on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 rose 0.8% to 6,774.76 on Thursday, snapping a four-day losing streak[6][7][8]. The Nasdaq Composite surged 1.4% to 23,006.36, driven by a rebound in technology stocks after Micron Technology reported quarterly revenue of $13.64 billion, exceeding analyst expectations of $12.88 billion[6][9][10].

items.title: Macron demands stronger farm protections in EU-Mercosur trade deal

featured_image.name: Mercosur: EU Parliament approves safeguard mechanism using mirror clauses

items.description:
French President Emmanuel Macron intensified his opposition to the European Union's trade agreement with South American Mercosur countries on Thursday, demanding stronger protections for European farmers as the deal's signing was postponed until January[1][2][3].

The European Commission announced the delay after Macron and Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni pressed for additional time to review newly adopted safeguard measures[1][2]. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen had planned to travel to Brazil for a signing ceremony on Saturday, but failed to secure the required backing from EU member states[4][2].

"The agreement is not ready and cannot be signed yet," Macron told reporters at the EU summit in Brussels[5]. "We cannot jeopardize the coherence of our agriculture, food production, and the safety of our citizens with an incomplete deal."

items.title: Parker Solar Probe maps sun's atmospheric edge

featured_image.name: NASA's Parker Solar Probe mapped an unseen part of the sun at its most active moment

items.description:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe confirmed normal operations Thursday following its 26th close approach to the sun, as scientists unveiled unprecedented maps of the star's outer atmosphere and observations of solar material making a dramatic U-turn back toward the solar surface.

The spacecraft completed its latest solar encounter on Dec. 13, matching its record distance of 3.8 million miles from the sun's surface while traveling at 430,000 mph, according to NASA[1][2]. Flight controllers at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory in Maryland received a beacon signal Thursday indicating the probe survived its journey through the sun's corona and is operating normally[1][2].

items.title: Interstellar comet nears Earth as NASA reports major 2025 discoveries

featured_image.name: An interstellar comet is passing by Earth tonight—here’s how to see it

items.description:
As an interstellar comet makes its closest approach to Earth today, NASA and international astronomers cap off 2025 with a year of discoveries that may reshape our understanding of the cosmos—from potential first glimpses of dark matter to evidence of the universe's earliest stars.

Comet 3I/ATLAS, the third confirmed interstellar visitor to our solar system, will pass within 270 million kilometers of Earth on December 19[1][2][3]. NASA coordinated observations using the James Webb Space Telescope, Hubble, and the Mars Perseverance rover to study the ancient wanderer, which may be older than our solar system itself[4][5]. The comet's unusually high carbon dioxide content and age offer scientists a rare window into the chemistry of distant star systems[6][5].

items.title: Antarctic ice melt could disrupt ocean currents vital to global climate

featured_image.name: A hidden Antarctic shift unleashed the carbon that warmed ...

items.description:
A delicate balance between melting ice shelves and sea ice production in Antarctica controls one of Earth's most crucial ocean currents, and climate change could tip the scales with potentially dire consequences for global weather patterns, according to new research published today.

Australian scientists have identified competing forces at Cape Darnley in East Antarctica that regulate the formation of Antarctic Bottom Water, an icy current that acts as a conveyor belt driving ocean circulation worldwide. The findings suggest that increased ice shelf melting or reduced sea ice could disrupt this system, affecting rainfall in Africa and temperatures in Europe[1][2][3].

"This very cold, salty water, called Antarctic Bottom Water, is formed by the freezing of the ocean surface in sea ice factories that we call polynyas," said Dr. David Gwyther of The University of Queensland, who led the research team. "This dense water sinks to the ocean floor where it flows northwards acting like a giant conveyor belt driving currents around the planet which influence the climate worldwide"[1][2][3].

items.title: US, EU sanction 70 shadow fleet vessels aiding Iran and Russia

featured_image.name: Shadow fleet — from smuggling to spying and sabotage

items.description:
The United States and European Union launched coordinated sanctions Wednesday targeting 70 vessels accused of helping Iran and Russia circumvent international oil export restrictions, marking a significant escalation in Western efforts to cut off revenue streams financing Tehran's military programs and Moscow's war in Ukraine.

The U.S. Treasury Department sanctioned 29 vessels and their management firms for transporting hundreds of millions of dollars worth of Iranian petroleum products through deceptive shipping practices, according to a Treasury statement[1][2]. On the same day, the European Union added 41 vessels to its blacklist, primarily targeting tankers moving Russian crude oil, along with nine individuals and entities linked to major Russian oil companies[3][4][5].

"As President Trump has said repeatedly, the United States will not allow Iran to have a nuclear weapon," Treasury Under Secretary for Terrorism and Financial Intelligence John K. Hurley said in the announcement[1][6]. "Treasury will continue to deprive the regime of the petroleum revenue it uses to fund its military and weapons programs."
